labels.analysis: The MCP Server described is focused on providing accurate datetime information to agentic systems and chat interfaces. Its primary function is to offer current time and date data, either in the local system timezone or through a configurable timezone via a URI scheme. This enables LLMs and other systems to incorporate precise temporal context into their operations, making it valuable for workflows that require time-sensitive decisions or logging.
labels.reasoning: The "Time & Calendar" category is the most appropriate Primary Label as the server's core function revolves around providing current datetime information, which is directly related to time management and scheduling. While it could also relate to productivity, its specific datetime focus makes "Time & Calendar" the most accurate descriptor. No secondary labels are needed as the functionality is clearly time-related.

tools.name: get-current-time
tools.description: Get the current time in the configured local timezone

server_info_crawled.name: Datetime Server
server_info_crawled.author: @jujiale/mcp-timeserver
server_info_crawled.overview: Provide current date and time information to agentic systems and chat REPLs. Access datetime data for various timezones via a simple URI scheme or retrieve the local system time through a tool. Enable LLMs to incorporate accurate and timely datetime context in their workflows.

tools.name: get-current-time
tools.description: Get the current time in the configured local timezone

server_info_crawled.python_sdk:
import mcp
from mcp.client.streamable_http import streamablehttp_client
import json
import base64

smithery_api_key = ""
url = f"https://server.smithery.ai/@jujiale/mcp-timeserver/mcp?api_key={smithery_api_key}"

async def main():
    # Connect to the server using HTTP client
    async with streamablehttp_client(url) as (read_stream, write_stream, _):
        async with mcp.ClientSession(read_stream, write_stream) as session:
            # Initialize the connection
            await session.initialize()
            # List available tools
            tools_result = await session.list_tools()
            print(f"Available tools: {', '.join([t.name for t in tools_result.tools])}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    import asyncio
    asyncio.run(main())
